ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Categorical Imperative changed the way I read every other author. Nietzsche changed my life.

Definitely pushed me to think critically about answering complex metaphysical questions from the viewpoints of different philosophers. I improved my ability to respond to philosophical issues proposed by philosopher Kant from the perspective of Hume, for example.
I learned how to think in a different way.

In Directed Studies, you learn to read, you learn to write, and you learn how to do more work than you can. DS Philosophy is particularly interesting in that it focuses more on the text, and less on your interpretation.
Developing critiques of arguments, speaking up in seminar, assessing and evaluating arguments in writing
How to think, literally. Philosophy taught me how to think.

By reading the different texts from all of these philosophers I learned that what I perceive about the world may not be the same thing as what the real world is. I also learned to look into what the self is and to question how the self is defined. I learned to analyze and evaluate different ideas and that sometimes seemingly opposing ideas can be combined together.

This course was a really great introduction to major movements in Western philosophical thought, and I enjoyed getting to step into another thinker's worldview every week. Through understanding different systems of thought, my favorites being Kant's Transcendental Aesthetic and Leibniz's Monadology, I improved my logical thinking and critique skills.
Speaking in class; academic writing

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Add Hegel! Professor Szabo sometimes wasn't great at keeping a queue, so sometimes it felt like I didn't have the opportunity to participate for a while if he was looking at the other side of the room.

Strengths: The content of the class is interesting. The philosophy in the second half of DS is definitely more challenging but that can be fun. Weakness: The content can be challenging, Szabo is a bit harsh on papers
The second half is much stronger than the first half.
In a word, DS is great. But DS Philosophy could focus more on your interpretations and insights, and a bit less on just understanding the text.

Strengths: the spring semester syllabus and material for DS Philosophy is fascinating and engaging 
Weaknesses: the pace of the course, but this is a feature of DS generally

It is really for people that are passionate about academia, and that is in reality both its strength and weakness. It attracts the same sort of people, but if you're not in that sort of mindset, you'll struggle, especially with philosophy. This applies to the rest of the DS curriculum.

The pace of the course often made it feel like we didnt get to discuss philosophers enough. I think removing a few texts could be valuable (spending less time on Kant for example, or removing Kierkegaard) to give us more time for others. I also feel like we missed out on a large group of philosophers by not reading Hegel (which allows us to read Marx and potentially Foucault)

The philosophy lectures were a great way to get a condensed and straightforward summary of each thinkers' main arguments, and I think the learning experience could be improved through a more structured seminar. Since I wasn't familiar with the texts we were reading and sometimes struggled to get clarity on basic concepts, it would have been helpful to have a set agenda with topics we would cover in depth. I think that the seminars mostly consisted of various students asking their own questions about the text, which although helpful, was not conducive to maintaining a continued conversation. Also, something I struggled with this year was understanding how to best participate or structure papers in a philosophy class, since students usually have less of a background in that field compared to something like literature. It would be really helpful if professors can provide outlines on how to structure the essay.
I enjoyed the reading material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Do NOT drop DS! The second semester changes your life.
Yes, but be prepared to put a lot of extra time into understanding the concepts before seminar.
Yes if you like philosophy or want to try philosophy.
I would. I can vouch that Professor Szabo is a good professor to take it withgreat at explaining, friendly, and not the hardest grader (though its not an easy A).
Yes! A great introduction to modern philosophy and a very intellectually stimulating course overall
Yes, if they enjoy the process of learning in general!

On DS philosophy in general: If you're on the fence about DS because you are not sure whether you want to take philosophy, I would say that the strength of the other two tracks and the fact that you will at least find some philosophers who totally change your view of the world make it worth it. As someone without philosophy experience, learning about immaterialism and monads was hard and Kant is difficult to read, but by the end, I truly felt like I had an introductory grasp of Western philosophy, and I'm very glad that I got to get it in a seminar with peers who often would be very knowledgeable and a professor who was active in facilitating discussion. 

On this section: Prof. Szabo is good philosophy professor and very knowledgeable, but if you want someone who creates agendas for discussion sections and offers lots of office hours and feedback, perhaps look into other sections. Prof. Szabo is involved with his students and does offer feedback on essays and office hours by appointment, but you get the sense that out of his classes, a first-year philosophy seminar is probably not his top priority (which is okay and understandable and he was still incredible to learn from, but there are other philosophy professors who may have different priorities).

This course provided a thorough survey of philosophers influential to the Western cannon, and I think that even if you're not interested in going into philosophy, it provides a good framework for how thought has evolved, particularly how. we come to understand the self and how we process experience. As a student, I thought that the spring philosophy prompts were more challenging compared to the fall, since the systems of thought became more rigorous.
Yes
